name: Fynn
headline: SoFi for trade students
description: Fynn helps people afford trade school in the US. We bring fair and affordable private loans to the trade space, to help students pursue in-demand careers like electricians, nurses, welders, or pharmacists.

founders.name: Ethan Anderson, Founder
founders.description:
RISD -> Droga5 -> Fynn. I work on product and operations. 

Interested in operationally complex areas, built environments, fintech, and unsexy moats.

generated_description:
**Fynn: Empowering Trade Students through Financial Accessibility**

Fynn, founded in 2019 and hailing from Y Combinator's Summer 2019 batch, is a New York-based fintech company addressing a crucial gap in the education financing landscape. Think of Fynn as "SoFi for trade students." Their mission is straightforward yet impactful: to make trade school more affordable for aspiring electricians, nurses, welders, and pharmacists.

With a team of 26 dedicated employees, Fynn focuses on providing fair and accessible private loans specifically tailored for trade students. This initiative is especially vital as these in-demand careers often require financial support to pursue education and training.

The company stands at the intersection of two thriving sectors: education and fintech. Their approach reduces the financial barriers that many students face, enabling them to embark on rewarding careers in trades that are not only fulfilling but also critical to the workforce.

Fynn is part of the fintech revolution, leveraging technology to innovate and streamline the educational financing process. By bringing transparency and fairness to the loan market for trade education, they empower students to chase their dreams without the crippling burden of debt.

For those interested in learning more about Fynn and the services they provide, you can visit their website at [fynncredit.com](https://www.fynncredit.com). 

In summary, Fynn is an essential player in the growing movement to democratize access to vocational education, ensuring that the next generation of skilled workers has the financial means to succeed.
